trial_identification.studytitle: Effect of atropine eye drops on thinning of the ocular choroid induced by retinal image defocus in adults with myopia (near-sightedness)
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Effect of atropine eye drops on choroidal thinning induced by hyperopic retinal defocus in adults with myopia

interventions.interventions: One drop 0.5% atropine eye drop to non-dominant eye on one occasion, instilled by the research optometrist
interventions.comparator: Sequential no-treatment - treatment study in same eye. No additional control group

primaryOutcome.outcome: Change in sub-foveal choroidal thickness (measured with swept source optical coherence tomography) in response to imposed retinal defocus with 2.00 Dioptre lens
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Before and 22 hours after 1 drop of 0.5% atropine

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Change in para-foveal choroidal thickness (measured using swept source optical coherence tomography) in response to imposed retinal defocus with 2.00 Dioptre lens
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: before and 22 hours after 1 drop of 0.5% atropine

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: The inclusion criteria for this study were: Spherical Equivalent Refraction (SER) with spectacle prescription between -1.00 to -5.00 D, with little astigmatism (= 1.00 D) or anisometropia (= 1.00 D).
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Individuals with amblyopia, ocular pathology or other ocular anomalies (e.g. surgery, trauma) that might have influenced the measurements were excluded.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Myopia of any degree increases the risk of developing sight-threatening conditions such as glaucoma, retinal detachment and myopic maculopathy with risk increasing dramatically with progression to high myopia. Atropine eye drops are currently the most effective treatment for managing myopia progression, but the mode of action is unclear. The aim of this study was to investigate the effect of atropine eye drops on choroidal thinning induced by hyperopic retinal defocus, using automated measures of choroidal thickness obtained with swept-source optical coherence tomography (SS-OCT). A secondary aim was to record the short-term effect of atropine on the resting thickness of the choroid.
